ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
At the Chemours Co. - Corpus Christi Plant we are committed to operating and maintaining our process in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as the protection of the environment.  The Chemours Co. - Corpus Christi Plant adheres to Corporate policies, which could be summarized as follows:
                            - All Safety and Environmental Incidents Are Preventable
                            - The Goal Is Zero - Zero Incidents, Period
                            - All Employees and Contractors Are Responsible For Their Safety
The Corporate policies are embodied in the numerous site safety and engineering procedures and guidelines.  At the Chemours Co. - Corpus Christi Plant, the policies are implemented through the Process Safety and Risk Management Procedures Manual and the Emergency Response Procedures Manual.  These manuals are available to all site employees electronically and with annual computer based training.
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Chemours Co. - Corpus Christi Plant consists of approximately 580 acres, located in a rural setting along Highway 361 between the cities of Ingleside and Gregory.  About 200 acres of the property is industrialized while the remaining 400 acres is used for agricultural purposes.  The industrialized area consists of a single manufacturing complex that produces ozone friendly hydrofluorocarbon refrigerant, HFC-134a,HFO-1234yf and aerosol propellant, HFC-152a.  In the production of these products, the following RMP regulated substances are used as raw materials or intermediates or products.
- Hydrogen Chloride, anhydrous               
- Hydrogen Fluoride, anhydrous
- Difluoroethane (HFC-152a) 
- Chloroform
- Propane

The Chemours Corporate Guardian Committee's for hydrogen fluoride and hydrogen chloride are utilized to provide guidance in safe handling and risk management practices.  These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards of accident prevention.
FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
We keep records for all accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  It is our philosophy and practice that all accidental releases, regardless of  and significance, are tracked to identify and correct the key cause of the event.  The Chemours Co. - Corpus Chrisit Plant has an excellent safety record and accidental release prevention history.   There has been one accidental release of a RMP regulated substances in the past 5 years that meets the RMP resubmission criteria.  The accidental release resulted in an on-site employee exposure to a RMP regulated substance that was an OSHA recordable injury.  There were no off-site impacts as a result of this accidental release.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting the workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  The program can be summarized as follows:  In order that plant personnel are prepared, an emergency response plan is in place and updated regularly and all employees are trained for their role in the emergency response plan.  Since site operates on a 24 hour basis, the operations personnel comprise the on-site emergency response team.  The emergency response team is led by the shift team leader who acts as the incident commander and emergency response contact.  There are eight shift team leaders and detail shift team le

aders any one of them is available at any given time to direct emergency response.  The plant participates in emergency drills, both on-site and off-site.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  The plant site is a founding member and active supporter of the Coastal Plain Local Emergency Planning Committee.  We coordinate our plan with the San Patricio County emergency response plan.  If a major release occurs, the emergency alarm is sounded and the site's emergency control center is activated.  The site incident commander and emergency response team responds.  Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate and mutual aid agreements are exercised when necessary.  Incident investigations and corrective actions are identified and implemented.  The facility security plan meets and exceeds the Maritime Security (MTSA 105) regulations.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The following is a list of improvements that are on-going at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:
 - Continue to enhance the site's process hazard analysis procedure (risk matrices) to include guidance for conducting risk reduction analyses which will facilitate consistent risk reduction decisions among PHA teams.
 - Continue expanding the site's incident communication practice to include other incidents. Those events or situations that can lead to an incident or near miss so key learnings are broadly shared and recurring events are eliminated.
- Continue to improve community emergency planning and preparedness by actively supporting and leading the increased involvement and education of responders from neighboring counties and municipalities in the local emergency planning committee.
- Continue to strengthen and reinforce the strong employee mentoring program and safe work practices initiative.
- Continue improvements to further strengthen the overall mechanical integrity and quality assurance program.
- Continue to enhance th

e list of leading safety indicators for on-going analysis to improve the process safety management program.
- Continued the Safe Start behavior based safety program to enhance employee participation.
- Continued focus on our Committment to Zero for injuries and incidents.
- Continued reinforcement of Operational Discipline for all site employees, including contractors.
- Continue focus on process safety alarm rationalization to enhance operator response and effectiveness.
- Continue enhancements in the identification of process safety critical equipment and development of respective preventative maintenance plans.

TION STEPS
* We maintain a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operation.  The accident prevention programs in place are in compliance wih the OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) rule and the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule.  For our efforts in safety excellence, the Chemours Co. - Corpus Christi Plant is recognized by the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program as a STAR Work Site since 1984.  The facility's environmental management system is ISO 14001 certified since 2003.
* Our accident prevention and safety programs can be summarized into these elements.  Designing for Safety includes a documented process technology system covering the hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.  It includes an strategically located extensive accident prevention and mitigation system.  It includes the requirement to choose materials of construction to provide mechanical integrity.  It incorporates extensive safety instrumentation such as alarms, interlocks, and gas detectors.  Transportation vehicles are designed for safe handling.  Maintaining Our Plant includes identifying all process safety critical equipment and perfoming routine inspections to ensure proper operation and mechanical integrity.  High housekeeping standards contribute to safe operation practices.  Equipment specifications meet or exceed acceptable engineering standards.  A work order and permit system is used to control maintenance on the systems.  Maintenance personnel are trained, qualified, and experienced in preventative and predictive maintenance.  Operating Safely includes the requirement for operators and mechanics to follow approved procedures.  The process is continually monitored by computer control systems and operators.  Railcar transfers are under continuous surveillance by trained personnel.  And, even the subtlest changes are properly designed and completely documented.
